text: Allow for XPath's to be used in assertions.

creator: jspears@astrology.com
text:
Created attachment 13915
XPath Assertion

Included is a patch for  XPath assertions and the associated
gui for configuring the assertions.  ( XPath is a powerful method for selecting

things from XML files.	www.w3.org/TR/xpath .)If the xpath is found and the
document is parsable then the assertion is true.
It has the following three options.
1. Validate (validate the xml against the DTD)
2. Ignore Element White space.
3. Tidy -Tidy feeds the file through the tidy, so that the xpath can be used
with HTML. 
It also has an input field for matching XPaths, and a button
to test weather the XPath expression is valid.	

This patch could superceed XML Assertion as an XPath expression
of / would do same thing as XML Assertion.  So this can both test
a document for well formed-ness and/or validness. 

In order for this to superceed XML Assertion, it would need to be renamed
XMLAssertion. In addition the message resources would need to be modified 
to reflect the menu correctly.	Since XMLAssertion does not have any
properties, this should be otherwise compatibable.

Note I posted a similar patch on the mailing list... my bad, but that
patch requires jdom's XPath jars  which in turn depend on jaxen and saxen. 

This patch has been rewritten to remove those dependencies.

Refactored XPath assertion

Created new panels for the xml and xpath assertion.  Also changed from using
JTidy to try and tidy up the output to using TolerantSAXBuilder from
xmlunit.org.  The copyright on the xmlunit files permit redistribution with /
without modification in source/binary, but requires that the copyright stays...
So I don't know exactly how to handle it.... 

But it seems to work Much better on badly formed HTML than TIdy... As tidy is
really ment for finding errors, not for parsing XML no-matta-what.

I've found that Tidy can be made to work better with malformed HTML, certainly
enough to allow it to handle the testTolerant() case.
[It was enough to call tidy.setXmlTags(false) i.e. input is not XML]

So I propose to include the new version of the code, but use Tidy until it has
been clarified that the xmlunit contributions can be used. [I'll comment out the
code that calls them, so it can be restored easily.]
